His strong left-wing views make him the devil incarnate to more extreme Conservatives.

meanings.def: a person who behaves badly, especially a child
examples: a naughty little devil

meanings.def: used to talk about somebody and to emphasize an opinion that you have of them
examples: I miss the old devil, now that he's gone.
She's off to Greece for a month—lucky devil!
James was a handsome devil and rich, too.
They were handsome young devils in their uniforms, weren't they?

meanings.def: people say Be a devil! to encourage somebody to do something that they are not sure about doing
examples: Go on, be a devil, buy both of them.

meanings.def: used to say that it is easier and wiser to stay in a bad situation that you know and can deal with rather than change to a new situation that may be much worse
in a difficult situation where there are two equally unpleasant or unacceptable choices

examples: These berries are the devil to pick because they're so small.

meanings.def: bad people often seem to have good luck
people who do not have enough to do often start to do wrong
examples: She blamed the crimes on the local jobless teenagers. ‘The devil makes work for idle hands,’ she would say.

meanings.def: a very difficult or unpleasant job or time
examples: I've had a devil of a job finding you.
There'll be hell to pay when he finds out.

meanings.def: used, in an unfriendly way, to tell somebody to go away

examples: We ran like the devil.

meanings.def: to do anything, even something really bad or dishonest, in return for money, success or power
people say speak/talk of the devil when somebody they have been talking about appears unexpectedly
examples: Well, speak of the devil—here's Alice now!

meanings.def: used in questions to show that you are annoyed or surprised
